author.ban_reason: Repeated deliberate violations of Guildmaster rules

body:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect? 

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.
body_html:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect?

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: It's fine, you don't have to even like your parents some people make shit parents. Basic respect should be enough, Jesus says those who do the will of his Father are his family, blood relations don't matter that much

body:
> until they lose it

Nope. You respect everyone whether they're good to you or not. Even some of the most evil people respect those who respect them.

until they lose it

body: You should still take care of your parents when they need it (and anyone else for that matter). The Pharisees used a loophole where they claimed if what would've gone to their parents was "devoted to God" then they could abandon them. Jesus wasn't too happy about that.
body_html: You should still take care of your parents when they need it (and anyone else for that matter). The Pharisees used a loophole where they claimed if what would've gone to their parents was "devoted to God" then they could abandon them. Jesus wasn't too happy about that.

body: I don't believe you necessarily owe to them per say but I do think it's your obligation to help them out. I think this extends to anyone you know who needs your help but if you don't do it, it's likely no one will. Remember the Pharisees found a loophole saying they could abandon their parents if what would've gone to them was "given to God" instead, and Jesus wasn't too happy about it.
body_html: I don't believe you necessarily owe to them per say but I do think it's your obligation to help them out. I think this extends to anyone you know who needs your help but if you don't do it, it's likely no one will. Remember the Pharisees found a loophole saying they could abandon their parents if what would've gone to them was "given to God" instead, and Jesus wasn't too happy about it.

body: The help my parents needs can only come from themselves - and they continually refuse. I wouldn't abandon them, though I would like to let their problems be their own, since they remain unresolved and unresolvable, by their own hands.
body_html: The help my parents needs can only come from themselves - and they continually refuse. I wouldn't abandon them, though I would like to let their problems be their own, since they remain unresolved and unresolvable, by their own hands.

For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God.

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
guild.name: Christianity

parent.body: I don't believe you necessarily owe to them per say but I do think it's your obligation to help them out. I think this extends to anyone you know who needs your help but if you don't do it, it's likely no one will. Remember the Pharisees found a loophole saying they could abandon their parents if what would've gone to them was "given to God" instead, and Jesus wasn't too happy about it.
parent.body_html: I don't believe you necessarily owe to them per say but I do think it's your obligation to help them out. I think this extends to anyone you know who needs your help but if you don't do it, it's likely no one will. Remember the Pharisees found a loophole saying they could abandon their parents if what would've gone to them was "given to God" instead, and Jesus wasn't too happy about it.

post.body:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect? 

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.
post.body_html:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect?

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.
post.title: Struggling with Commandment #5 - "Honour your father and mother."

post.body:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect? 

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.

How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect?

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.
post.title: Struggling with Commandment #5 - "Honour your father and mother."

body:
So the question seems clear about how to handle "good" or "honorable" parents, we're wondering how to deal with "dishonorable" or "bad" parents (objectively or subjectively speaking)

particularly I'm curious how heretical parents are dealt with, for:

> A man that is a heretic, after the first and second admonition, avoid (Titus 3:10)

I guess you can try to make sure parents are taken care of if possible; as they took care of a child and brought them up, so they can be taken care of in their old age

one's conscience is also a guide for doing what is right

you could pray to God for insight on how to honor "difficult" parents

You can also do good to those who do you evil as mentioned in the comments:

> But I say to you that hear: Love your enemies, do good to them that hate you. (Luke 6:27)

I'm not sure how the abuse of parents is to be dealt with, as there seem to be more cases of parental alienation and conflict between parents and children

Injuries could be patiently borne if they are within reason (hurtful comments, etc.)

The physically abusive parent, some people might just get away from and be distanced from; because of the danger of abuse, I'm not sure a person would be obliged to endure certain abuses (such actions that are criminal would be punished and seeking justice would not be contrary to honoring parents)

God is more important than family, for example:

> He that loveth father or mother more than me, is not worthy of me; and he that loveth son or daughter more than me, is not worthy of me. Matthew 10:37

(In the event of family conflicts where the interests of God are in conflict with that of the family)

> We honour our parents, from whom we received our earthly being, and to whom we owe our bringing-up and preparation for the battle of life. https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07462a.htm

I guess you could try to honor dishonorable parents, while being able to in justice (depending on the dishonor given) being able to defend your own honor against the dishonor they offer. Perhaps some parents are worthy of more honor than other parents, but there is still like a base level of honor all parents are supposed to have for bringing up a child?

So the question seems clear about how to handle "good" or "honorable" parents, we're wondering how to deal with "dishonorable" or "bad" parents (objectively or subjectively speaking)

particularly I'm curious how heretical parents are dealt with, for:

A man that is a heretic, after the first and second admonition, avoid (Titus 3:10)

I guess you can try to make sure parents are taken care of if possible; as they took care of a child and brought them up, so they can be taken care of in their old age

one's conscience is also a guide for doing what is right

you could pray to God for insight on how to honor "difficult" parents

You can also do good to those who do you evil as mentioned in the comments:

But I say to you that hear: Love your enemies, do good to them that hate you. (Luke 6:27)

I'm not sure how the abuse of parents is to be dealt with, as there seem to be more cases of parental alienation and conflict between parents and children

Injuries could be patiently borne if they are within reason (hurtful comments, etc.)

The physically abusive parent, some people might just get away from and be distanced from; because of the danger of abuse, I'm not sure a person would be obliged to endure certain abuses (such actions that are criminal would be punished and seeking justice would not be contrary to honoring parents)

God is more important than family, for example:

He that loveth father or mother more than me, is not worthy of me; and he that loveth son or daughter more than me, is not worthy of me. Matthew 10:37

(In the event of family conflicts where the interests of God are in conflict with that of the family)

We honour our parents, from whom we received our earthly being, and to whom we owe our bringing-up and preparation for the battle of life. https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07462a.htm

I guess you could try to honor dishonorable parents, while being able to in justice (depending on the dishonor given) being able to defend your own honor against the dishonor they offer. Perhaps some parents are worthy of more honor than other parents, but there is still like a base level of honor all parents are supposed to have for bringing up a child?

Professional Chrischan. Striving for post-Enlightenment reconciliation. I love Jesus and hate the antichrist. ✝️ #NotAll

body:
You have to take the old commandments in their historical context. You would rely on your family's wealth to survive back then, there was no going to college, having a career of your own, and becoming your own man. It's a completely different paradigm.

It's not command to unconditional loyalty. It's more like "Don't bite the hand that feeds you."
body_html:
